channel.title: american – Chow Down Orlando
channel.description: Exploring all that Orlando has to offer.

item.title: On the Road: Angel’s Dining Car
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
The second stop on our north Florida diner tour is Angel’s Dining Car in Palatka. Like Powell’s the other day, Angel’s is a classic diner featuring curbside service and outdoor picnic tables. But Angel’s is something more, it’s actually an old fashioned dining car turned into stationary restaurant. A step inside the dining car feels […]

The post On the Road: Angel’s Dining Car appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
The second stop on our north Florida diner tour is Angel’s Dining Car in Palatka. Like Powell’s the other day, Angel’s is a classic diner featuring curbside service and outdoor picnic tables. But Angel’s is something more, it’s actually an old fashioned dining car turned into stationary restaurant. A step inside the dining car feels like a step back in time.

Angel’s has been open since 1939 and features classic diner food like milkshakes, great burgers and onion rings, but also has some unique features like the Black Bottom (pictured with the blue toothpick).

The Black Bottom is hamburger meat, egg, and bacon cooked into a hamburger patty shape to create the ultimate breakfast/lunch hybrid burger. Like Powell’s, Angel’s amazing food comes with prices from days gone by. The Swiss Burger combo pictured, which came with fries and onion rings, was comparable to a combo meal at a fast food place. And considering the quality is far better than any fast food place, you’d be hard pressed not to stop at Angel’s if in the area.

Angel’s Dining Car can be found in Palatka on Reid St.

The post On the Road: Angel’s Dining Car appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.

item.title: On the Road: Powell’s Dairy Freeze
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
This week is the North Florida Diner Tour here at Chow Down Orlando. We hit the back roads and visited some of the local gems in some of the small towns north of Orlando. If you find yourself looking for some day trips, there’s some great food to be had. The first on the tour […]

The post On the Road: Powell’s Dairy Freeze appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
This week is the North Florida Diner Tour here at Chow Down Orlando. We hit the back roads and visited some of the local gems in some of the small towns north of Orlando. If you find yourself looking for some day trips, there’s some great food to be had.

The first on the tour is Powell’s Dairy Freeze in Starke. Powell’s is a classic “dairy freeze” in that there is a walk up window and some picnic tables outside. They also offer curbside service like all classic Americana diners.

While at Powell’s, I tried a banana shake and a “Super Burger.” The shake was real ice cream and chunks of banana. It perfectly made. The “Super Burger” was everything a great diner burger should be: two hand-pressed patties cooked on the flattop, cheese, onion, lettuce, and hand sliced tomato, with some “super” sauce. It was great.

The flavors in the burger and shake were spot on delicious. But when you consider the old school pricing at Powell’s, they’re even better. The shake and burger were under $6. A downright steal.

Powell’s is a true American diner and can be found in Starke on North Temple Ave.

The post On the Road: Powell’s Dairy Freeze appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.

item.title: Toasted
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
Since today is July 4th, there isn’t anything more American than a good grilled cheese. So today we bring to you Toasted in Winter Park. Toasted opened earlier this year and is everything cheese. They even have a periodic table of cheeses on the wall. I had a Southern Comfort burger, which is topped with bacon, cheddar, […]

The post Toasted appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
Since today is July 4th, there isn’t anything more American than a good grilled cheese. So today we bring to you Toasted in Winter Park. Toasted opened earlier this year and is everything cheese. They even have a periodic table of cheeses on the wall.

I had a Southern Comfort burger, which is topped with bacon, cheddar, mac n cheese and a homemade bbq sauce. It was great. The burger was cooked to medium and had a nice flavor. Combined with the cheese and the mac n cheese, this burger was plenty cheesy and who doesn’t like a good bacon?

Carla had the Fig & Goat grilled cheese sandwich, which had havarti, fig spread, goat cheese, basil, and honey. It was a great alternative take on the classic grilled cheese.

In an genius move, Toasted sells $1.50 “dippers” of tomato soup which is the perfect size to dip your sandwich into. We also shared a basket of truffle fries, which for $2.50 was a great deal with great flavor.

Overall, Toasted has great flavor for a very reasonable price. You can find them in Winter Park.

The post Toasted appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.

item.title: Hot Dog Heaven
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
I’ve been wanting to try Hot Dog Heaven for a long while now. Every time I drive by it’s location on Colonial near the 436 intersection, the giant hot dog sign tempts me. Finally, after years of wondering what was inside, I got a taste of their famous Chicago-style dogs. Hot Dog Heaven isn’t going […]

The post Hot Dog Heaven appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been wanting to try Hot Dog Heaven for a long while now. Every time I drive by it’s location on Colonial near the 436 intersection, the giant hot dog sign tempts me. Finally, after years of wondering what was inside, I got a taste of their famous Chicago-style dogs.

Hot Dog Heaven isn’t going to blow you away with flashy choices and gourmet toppings. They’re going to give you exactly what you would expect at a hot dog place: classic Chicago style (pictured), chili dogs, chili cheese dogs, slaw dogs, etc. But what they do, they do very well.

The classic Chicago style is topped with neon relish, onions, tomatoes, peppers, mustard, and on a poppy seed bun. It’s everything I had wanted it to be and then some. I’m a sucker for a good Chicago dog and Hot Dog Heaven filled that craving. Carla ordered the spicy chili dog. There was cayenne pepper worked into the hot dog which she said was a very nice touch.

All in all, Hot Dog Heaven isn’t going to wow you with decor or fancy choices, but what they are going to give you is a really good hot dog.

You can find Hot Dog Heaven at the corner of 50 and 436.

The post Hot Dog Heaven appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.

item.title: Fork in the Road
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
Fork in the Road has stepped up their game since the last time I visited them. Then it was just quality desserts and some sandwiches, but now the fare is on another level and, according to the menu board, Fork in the Road is the Best Gourmet Food Truck for 2013. The menu was intriguing […]

The post Fork in the Road appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
Fork in the Road has stepped up their game since the last time I visited them. Then it was just quality desserts and some sandwiches, but now the fare is on another level and, according to the menu board, Fork in the Road is the Best Gourmet Food Truck for 2013. The menu was intriguing with a lot of unique options, but what stood out most to me was the American Kobe Beef Corn Dog.

Essentially it’s exactly what it sounds like, a large, quality beef hot dog encased in a type of batter and fried. It was served with a pink mustard that had a sweetness (I’m guessing from whatever colored the mustard pink) that gave the mustard a pretty unique flavor.

All in all it was a pretty good corn dog as far as corn dogs go. You can find Fork in the Road on Facebook.

The post Fork in the Road appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.

item.title: The Big Cheese
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
The Big Cheese is a new food truck here in Orlando serving up unique grilled cheese combinations. This one combines a sweet bbq pulled pork with a creamy macaroni and cheese, between two grilled pieces of toast of course. It’s an amazing combination that seems like a no-brainer in hindsight, but is delicious. The truck […]

The post The Big Cheese appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
The Big Cheese is a new food truck here in Orlando serving up unique grilled cheese combinations. This one combines a sweet bbq pulled pork with a creamy macaroni and cheese, between two grilled pieces of toast of course. It’s an amazing combination that seems like a no-brainer in hindsight, but is delicious.

The truck offered a number of other combinations, plus build your own options with all the ingredients. And honestly, who doesn’t like a nice grilled cheese sandwich?

You can find The Big Cheese on Twitter.

The post The Big Cheese appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.

item.title: On the Road: Phish Phood
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
This is another installment of Chow Down Orlando on the road, this time from Atlanta. The final stop on our greater Atlanta trip was Phish Phood, a sandwich shop that’s opened for lunch and dinner in the Roswell area. It’s a very cool neighborhood spot that is serving up food with a good amount of love […]

The post On the Road: Phish Phood appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
This is another installment of Chow Down Orlando on the road, this time from Atlanta.

The final stop on our greater Atlanta trip was Phish Phood, a sandwich shop that’s opened for lunch and dinner in the Roswell area. It’s a very cool neighborhood spot that is serving up food with a good amount of love and care.

We got a Ricky Ricardo, which is basically a fancy cuban with pork that they smoke in house. The other is the TunaPhish Pocket, which is kicked up tunafish in a peta. Both were served with Phish Chips and we asked for a side of their sweet thai chili blueberry sauce because it sounded so great.

The food was wonderful as were the friendly staff and owners. If we lived in the area, Phish Food would be on that list with Pom Pom as one of our go to places.

Next time you find yourself in Roswell, GA, give Phish Phood a try.

The post On the Road: Phish Phood appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.

item.title: Epcot Food and Wine 2011
item.dc:creator: justincox
item.description:
Every fall Epcot brings the International Food and Wine Festival to the park and gives park guests an opportunity to dine around the world, sampling flavors from nearly two dozen different regions. This year was our first visit to the Food and Wine Festival and I’d consider it a huge success. We  were both very […]

The post Epcot Food and Wine 2011 appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
item.content:encoded:
Every fall Epcot brings the International Food and Wine Festival to the park and gives park guests an opportunity to dine around the world, sampling flavors from nearly two dozen different regions. This year was our first visit to the Food and Wine Festival and I’d consider it a huge success.

We  were both very surprised with the size of the different dishes. Considering this is Disney we’re talking about, the price to food option was pretty amazing. These were perfectly portioned small plates that were mostly delicious. There wasn’t a single dish that we regretted purchasing.

These are the dishes that we tried and that are pictured above:

  • Seared Mahi Mahi from Brazil – $4.50
  • Nuernberger Sausage in a Pretzel Roll from Germany – $4.50
  • Pumpkin Mousse with Craisins and Orange Sauce from Hops and Barley – $1.50
  • Pork Kakuni from Japan – $4.95
  • Pastel de Nata from Portugal – $3.00
  • Belgium Waffle from Belgium – $3.00
  • Creme Brûlée au Chocolat au Lait from France – $3.95
  • Griddled Greek Cheese with Pistachios and Honey – $3.25
  • Tuna Poke with Seaweed Salad and Lotus Chips from Hawai’i – $3.75
  • Kalua Pork Slider from Hawai’i – $3.00

Everything was delicious, but there were a few items that stood out among the others. Namely the Pork Kakuni from Japan. Described on the fantastic mobile website as “slow-cooked for hours in Japanese sauces and seasonings” this pork completely melted in our mouths. It was simply put, amazing.

Also amazing, and what could also be given the best value of the entire event, is the Pumpkin Mousse with Orange Sauce. At only $1.50 this little mousse was more savory than sweet and packed a ton of flavor. It was Thanksgiving in a shot glass that you eat with a spoon. So very good.

Everything was so very good and we had so much fun walking around the lake at Epcot sampling all the different countries options. If you’ve never been, you should try and go. You’ll be happy you did.

The Epcot Food and Wine Festival is open until November 13th and is included with regular Epcot park admission.

The post Epcot Food and Wine 2011 appeared first on Chow Down Orlando.
